articles.headline: Boeing 737 Max Official Is Out as Questions Linger on Mishap
articles.snippet: The head of the factory making Max jets is leaving the company as it faces scrutiny of an incident that left a hole in a plane’s fuselage in flight.
articles.abstract: The head of the factory making Max jets is leaving the company as it faces scrutiny of an incident that left a hole in a plane’s fuselage in flight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Wednesday that it was shaking up the leadership in its commercial airplanes unit after a harrowing incident last month during which a piece fell off a 737 Max 9 jet in flight.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Nvidia Says Growth Will Continue as A.I. Hits ‘Tipping Point’
articles.snippet: The A.I. chip maker’s revenue more than tripled, and profits rose ninefold. It also projected that its revenue would more than triple again.
articles.abstract: The A.I. chip maker’s revenue more than tripled, and profits rose ninefold. It also projected that its revenue would more than triple again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nvidia, the kingpin of chips powering artificial intelligence, on Wednesday released quarterly financial results that reinforced how the company has become one of the biggest winners of the artificial intelligence boom, and it said demand for its products would fuel continued sales growth.

articles.headline: Biden Mulling Plan That Could Restrict Asylum Claims at the Border
articles.snippet: The action under consideration could prevent people from making asylum claims during border crossing surges. The White House says it is far from a decision on the matter.
articles.abstract: The action under consideration could prevent people from making asylum claims during border crossing surges. The White House says it is far from a decision on the matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is considering executive action that could prevent people who cross illegally into the United States from claiming asylum, several people with knowledge of the proposal said Wednesday. The move would suspend longtime guarantees that give anyone who steps onto U.S. soil the right to ask for safe haven.
articles.byline: By Hamed Aleaziz, Charlie Savage, Maggie Haberman and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: New Freighters Could Ease Red Sea Cargo Disruptions
articles.snippet: Analysts and shipping executives say they expect costs to fall later this year as companies receive vessels they ordered two to three years ago.
articles.abstract: Analysts and shipping executives say they expect costs to fall later this year as companies receive vessels they ordered two to three years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the Houthi militia started attacking container ships in the Red Sea last year, the cost of shipping goods from Asia soared by over 300 percent, prompting fears that supply chain disruptions might once again roil the global economy.

articles.headline: Leaked Files Show the Secret World of China’s Hackers for Hire
articles.snippet: China has increasingly turned to private companies in campaigns to hack foreign governments and control its domestic population.
articles.abstract: China has increasingly turned to private companies in campaigns to hack foreign governments and control its domestic population.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hackers offered a menu of services, at a variety of prices.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Keith Bradsher, John Liu and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: Instagram’s Uneasy Rise as a News Site
articles.snippet: In this year’s presidential election, more people are turning to Instagram for news, even as the platform tries de-emphasizing “political content.”
articles.abstract: In this year’s presidential election, more people are turning to Instagram for news, even as the platform tries de-emphasizing “political content.”
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent Wednesday in Brooklyn’s Dumbo neighborhood, Mosheh Oinounou, a former producer for CBS, Bloomberg News and Fox News, swiped through Instagram. He had started his morning reading major newspapers and more than a dozen newsletters. Then he spent much of the day turning many of the articles into posts on his Instagram account, under the handle Mo News.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Support for Teaching Gender Identity in School Is Split, Even Among Democrats
articles.snippet: Americans are deeply divided on whether schools should teach about gender identity, two polls found. But there was broader support for teaching about race.
articles.abstract: Americans are deeply divided on whether schools should teach about gender identity, two polls found. But there was broader support for teaching about race.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are deeply split over whether gender identity should be taught in school, according to two polls released this week that underscored the extent of the divide on one of the most contested topics in education.

articles.headline: Navalny’s Mother Says Authorities Are ‘Blackmailing’ Her Over Son’s Remains
articles.snippet: She said Russian authorities told her they would not release his remains unless she agreed to a “secret funeral.” Meanwhile, Aleksei Navalny’s widow met with President Biden.
articles.abstract: She said Russian authorities told her they would not release his remains unless she agreed to a “secret funeral.” Meanwhile, Aleksei Navalny’s widow met with President Biden.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russian authorities have declared that the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny died of natural causes but are refusing to release his remains until his family agrees to a “secret funeral,” Mr. Navalny’s mother and his spokeswoman said on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
